"Grand Theft Auto 3... Was one of the first 3D open worlds." Uhh... No. 3D open world games were being made for at least a decade when GTA 3 was released. GTA 3 released in 2001. I vividly remember playing 1991's Hunter on Amiga 600, and that was a 3D polygon open sandbox world, in which you could do missions, use a huge variety of weapons, and drive a surprising number of vehicles, including cars, bikes, tanks, boats, helicopters, and more. That was a full decade before GTA 3, and I'm fairly sure Hunter wasn't the first.

Even the developer of GTA 3 - DMA Design, had made a fully 3D open world sandbox type game in 1998. It was called Body Harvest, and it too had a number of weapons to use, and a ridiculous amount of vehicles, including boats and aircraft. So GTA 3 wasn't even the first open world game made by DMA Design, let alone one of the first ever made.

2 errors in the video to be aware of:
It is called the Gameboy ADVANCE SP, not Gameboy SP. The SP was the same tech as the Gameboy Advance, but solved some issues by adding a backlight and putting it in a foldable clamshell case, etc.
And the Gameboy DS is not a thing. (How did this mistake make it through so many nerds?)
The Nintendo DS is not part of the gameboy line. The Nintendo DS and the Gameboy Advance were meant to both be supported by Nintendo for years to come, alongside the Gamecube. And they were. However, eventually the GBA was phased out, and the DS Lite included a GBA cart slot so that you could play GBA and DS games on the handheld. This helped boost the popularity of the DS line even more, and helped it reach over 150 million units sold.

1900 titles on PS2.... sounds big until you realize how many Steam users today have that many games in their personal library!  I'm closing in on 1,500 games at this point!

PS2 was not 128bit.  No 128bit computer has ever been made.  That was ridiculously and overtly false advertising at the time and Sony took a lot of heat for making that up.  They claimed that by having two 64bit processors that they could add the numbers together to say that the bit rating of the computer was higher.  That's not at all how that works.  If that were true, modern computers wouldn't be 64bit but would be 720bit or higher.  Obviously they are not.  64bit is still today the highest that any commercially produced computer has ever been and 128bit isn't even on the horizon yet.  The PS2 still ran a 64bit OS, ran on a  64bit CPU and didn't even remotely push any bounds of 64bit ness.  Calling it 128bit is completely incorrect and Sony's marketing should not be used as reference material for education.  bad fact checking process there.

Guys, I love this honestly but you're missing a critical element to video game history that was happening at the same time as these consoles were duking it out:

The sensation of korean online E-sports, the innovation of the RTS namely starting with the first Command & Conquer and WC1 then jumping lightyears ahead with STARCRAFT!

Also, let's not forget about the critical importance of Half-Life's modding community which lead to... COUNTER STRIKE.

Honestly, so far I'm impressed with this crash course so far, but this will be a very weird take on video game history if you don't backtrack chronologically for a moment and seriously give a nod to counter strike, starcraft, mod community gaming, and korean e-sports.

It feels like this series is simply ignoring everything that was going on in the PC world. Next week, we're going into casual gaming. Wait, what? How is this less important to the history of gaming than the development of multiple new genres on PC, the first MMORPGs, the first multiplayer shooters, the creation of intricate WRPGs, and all the other PC innovations? How is STEAM not being mentioned in the same episode as X-Box Live? Not only that, if we're going in chronological order, the big changes in PC gaming occurred before the big casual market.

And really, I recognize how big a change casual gaming is in the world, but really. There's a giant, obvious elephant in the room that this series hasn't talked about at all.

I'm not going to say XBOX didn't contribute anything good to the video game industry, but they did reign in an era of non-gamer business monsters infecting and corrupting the industry. Microsoft bought its way into the space with no real understanding of the medium, all they knew was it was making lots of money and they wanted a piece of the pie. They invented and spread the culture of mass appeal/low quality/high profit video games that EA/ubisoft/and others followed with. they spent the last 10-20 years buying talent and ruining it, with a few good outcomes here and there, but otherwise there is no real 1st party for microsoft because they aren't a gaming business they are just a business that happens to trade in video games.

they have gotten wiser and keener to the market in more recent years since spencer joined the team, but im still very wary of them, there is no heart and soul at the brass of microsoft/xbox division, just a fake politicians/businessmans cheesy sales pitch trying to gain market dominance to make maximum profit with little REAL concern for consumer satisfaction

The GameCube did not use mini DVD-ROM. It uses a special proprietary format called GD-ROM. Which is why if you try to put one in a computer its not recognizable. some Panasonic drives I believe can read them, but they are few and far between. One last note. The Nintendo DS did stand for Dual Screen but it also stood for Developer System.

Morale choice systems which effected the world have been around since the 70s.

Along with built in network capability there was also the internal hard disk drive that was included.  It allowed games with larger save files like Morrowind to played on console instead of just PC.  It also allowed for downloading expansions and maps.  PlayStation had one that could be snapped in to it but developers didn't support it much because of the price.  I only recall FFXI requiring it.

4:10 this scared me

Cool. Can we make GTA 3 the last M rated game we show footage from like this? They got those ratings for a reason and even though the standards have shifted such that the bloodless running over of pedestrians in GTA 3 isn't shocking anymore - this is still a course aimed primarily at kids. The ability to run over pedestrians like that is part of what enabled GTA to gain that rating, and the fidelity of the graphics isn't supposed to be an excuse. It is supposed to be about the content's context.

We wouldn't show the scenes from a 1970's horror movie that earned it an R rating in a show for kids just because the fake blood and bad prosthetics are laughable by today's standards.

I almost said something about it with the Mortal Kombat footage as well. These games, even when released years later, still carry their original M ratings; for these ratings to be a value, they must be consistently applied and respected. The games industry is self regulated, if it wishes to remain self regulated those standards need to be followed by everyone involved, that's the threat that created the ESRB in the first place and while it can be argued that to discuss the ratings system it is important to show the context under which it was created and therefore it was valid to show Mortal Kombat, that excuse doesn't work for GTA.

I don't like the arbitrary nature of ratings systems at all, but if it is between them and having a government censorship body overseeing games - like radio has - I'll take the self regulation. If the powers that be wanted to, they could attack games again and threaten us with censorship like last time if they decide the ESRB isn't effective. We dance on that line every day. And in a year where the executives of a new WWI shooter talk about almost not greenlighting it because they didn't think their young audience would even know it happened, well, we should really try to be more careful.

GTA 3 probably won't get us in trouble. But basically anything moving forward into more modern eras of gaming might.

No. I'm done watching this. The lack of research is stupendiously dumb. All processors in consoles since the 64-bit one are still 64-bit, but have built upon those processor types. There has never been a "128 bit" console just like how we still dont have 128-bit PCs as of yet.
I'm sure you've been innundated with this... but the DS was not part of the Gameboy line. The Gameboy Micro was thelast Gameboy, iirc.
PlayStation 2 got a system refresh that added Dual Layered DVD support too.

I feel that we are missing a big part of gaming. Yes we talked about the evolution of board game, but boy was there some innovation during the industrial revolution and the modern era. Yes electronic game is huge now, but table game, card and collectible game, board game, role-playing game, simulation game... and those are only the ones I know/played; they were all intrinsic to the evolution of what we can now find in video games. And we have not even gloss over them. Just the trend of game style during the world wars era would have been such an interesting episode.
Anyway; the show is awesome, don't get me wrong. Keep up the good work, and I hope it will be successful enough so you can make a comeback on those topics.

Feel like this should have commented on the Dreamcast during the PS2 segment, since it beat the PS2 out the door in both being a 128bit system and being online connected. Difference was the online connection was in the Dreamcast by default and thus much better supported. Phantasy Star Online was the entry point for countless players into the MMO genre.
GameBoy SP? This was mostly a form factor update to the GameBoy Advance, in fact it was called the GameBoy Advance SP

If you think the PS2 had a long life, the Sega Master System (the system Sega developed before the Genesis) actually is STILL being officially produced. Brazil has MASSIVE taxes and tariffs for gaming consoles made outside of the nation), a PS4 costs 3,999 real (Brazil's national currency) which is about 1,800 US dollars, and extremely restrictive gaming ratings laws. However, decades ago, Sega licensed the design of their console to be produced in Brazil, allowing it to be MASSIVELY cheaper than any of it's legal competition, with new models coming prebuilt with over a hundred games.

Supposedly the name "X-Box" actually came from "DirectX-Box" and one of Microsoft's major incentives to develop for it was their new DirectX graphics API where developer could make their games for this API and have it run on PCs and X-Boxes without having to code directly for the specific GPU in the system, a trend that has become standard in the 3D graphics and gaming industries.
